The Act may be cited as the "10,000 Trained by 2011 Act" and includes findings. The National Science Foundation is recognized for its role in strengthening the nation's information infrastructure and supporting research in automation and digitization. Its assistance in basic research and curriculum development is crucial for industries to leverage advanced communications and information technology. Information management is projected to grow significantly in key sectors related to biology by 2010. Information management is projected to grow by 49 percent in key sectors related to biology by 2010. There is no systematic plan in place for designing and implementing systems and information tools to help the workforce transition to the information age. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

Director - The Director of the National Science Foundation.
Information - Data in sectors where the Federal Government is involved and transitioning to digital data use.
Institution of higher education - Defined as per section 101 of the Higher Education Act of 1965.

SEC. 4. NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION RESEARCH. The Director, in consultation with other Federal agencies, awards grants for research on improving information systems in areas like information studies, population informatics, translational informatics, and data security. Grants are merit-reviewed and competitive, with authorized appropriations for fiscal years 2008-2010. The Director awards multiyear grants to institutions of higher education to establish Centers for Informatics Research, with appropriations of $3.5 million for 2008, $3.6 million for 2009, $3.7 million for 2010, and $3.8 million for 2011. Institutions may partner with government, for-profit, or nonprofit entities. The Centers for Informatics Research are established through multiyear grants awarded to higher education institutions. These centers aim to conduct innovative, multidisciplinary research in information technology, partnering with government, for-profit, or nonprofit entities. Grants are awarded based on merit and competition, with applications submitted to the Director as required. The Centers for Informatics Research are established through grants awarded to higher education institutions. Applicants must submit an application to the Director with details on research projects, promoting collaboration among professionals from different disciplines, and contributing to increasing knowledge. The Center for Informatics Research aims to support professionals in fields transitioning to digital dependence and increase the number of information researchers. The Director evaluates applications based on innovative approaches, research experience, and collaboration capacity. The Director evaluates applications for the Center for Informatics Research based on research experience, collaboration capacity, and support for students. An annual meeting is convened to foster collaboration among the Centers. The Director evaluates applications for the Center for Informatics Research based on research experience, collaboration capacity, and support for students. An annual meeting is convened to foster collaboration among the Centers. Funding of $4.5 million for fiscal year 2008, $4.6 million for fiscal year 2009, $4.7 million for fiscal year 2010, and $4.8 million for fiscal year 2011 is authorized for the National Science Foundation. SEC. 5. NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION INFORMATION PROGRAMS. The Director, in consultation with other Federal agencies, will establish a program to award grants to institutions of higher education to improve undergraduate and master's degree information programs, increase student enrollment in information fields, provide industry experience, and promote distance learning. Grants will be awarded based on merit and competition, and funds must be used for activities enhancing program abilities. Grants awarded under this program will be based on merit and competition, and must be used to enhance higher education institutions' information education programs, including curriculum development, degree programs, and research opportunities in the information field. The grants aim to enhance higher education institutions' information education programs by establishing degree and certificate programs, creating research opportunities for students, acquiring necessary equipment, providing faculty collaboration opportunities, and working with other academic institutions to develop new research directions. The Director may collaborate with academic institutions to establish student internships, enhance bridge programs between community colleges and universities, and engage in other activities to achieve the grant's purposes. The Director, in consultation with other Federal agencies, may determine additional activities to achieve grant purposes. Institutions of higher education must submit applications for funding, including details on research and instructional capacity. The applicant must provide a description of their research and instructional capacity, a plan to build instructional capacity in information fields, collaborations with government agencies or private industry, and a survey of their historic activities. The applicant must provide a plan for collaborations with government agencies or private industry, historic student enrollment data, and a plan to evaluate the success of the proposed program. The Director will ensure awards are given accordingly. The Director will evaluate the program established under this subsection within 3 years to assess the grants' impact on increasing the quality and quantity of students pursuing undergraduate or master's degrees. Grants will be awarded in various geographic areas and categories of institutions of higher education. The Director will evaluate the program within 3 years to assess the impact of grants on students pursuing undergraduate or master's degrees in information fields. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2008 to 2011 under the Scientific and Advanced Technology Act of 1992. The Director will provide grants under the Scientific and Advanced Technology Act of 1992 to improve education in information-related fields. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2008 to 2011 is as follows: $7,000,000 for 2008, $7,200,000 for 2009, $7,400,000 for 2010, and $7,600,000 for 2011. SEC. 6. REPORT ON STANDARDIZATION OF MEASURES RELATED TO DIGITAL INFORMATION. The Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology must report to the House and Senate committees on informatics efforts, standards harmonization, research, and technical support for standards development organizations. The report should include timetables for information standards promulgation, challenges faced, efforts to ensure usability of digital information by scientists and researchers, and compliance with relevant laws. The National Institute of Standards and Technology must report on informatics efforts, standards harmonization, research, and technical support for standards development organizations. The report should include timetables for information standards promulgation, challenges faced, efforts to ensure usability of digital information by scientists and researchers, and actions to ensure robust and timely standards.
